I Summary of the Objects and Regulations of the Society/ ^ The RoDal Statistical Sucietij was fouuded un the lotli of Marcls, ^ K^LS:54, ill pursuance of a recommendation of the British Association \ c/>for tlie Advancement of Science, its objects being the careful \ >-collectiou, arrang-emeut, discussion and publication of facts bearing §ou and illustrating the complex relations of modern society in its Q^social, economical, and political aspects, especially facts which can 3be stated numerically and arranged in tables; and also, the foima- ti(jn of a Statistical Library as rapidly as its funds would permit. From its inception the Society has steadily progressed. It now possesses a valuable F^ibrary of over 50,000 volumes, and Reading Kooms. Monthly meetings, which are well attended and cultivate among its Fellows an active spirit of investigation, are held from November to June. The Papers read at these meetings, with an abstract of the discussions thereon, are published in the Journal, which now consists of eighty- four aminal volumes, and forms of itself a valuable lil)rary of reference. The Society has originated and statistically conducted many special inquiries on subjects of economic or social inteiest, of which the results have been published in the JournoJ, or issued separately. The Society is cosmopolitan, and consists of Fellows and 5 Honorary Fellows, together forming at the present time a body 52 of over nine, himdred members. Corporate bodies approved by the CO Council may become associated with the Society through a I-* representative. w The Fellows of the Society receive gratuitously a copy of each part of the Journai as publislied, and have the privilege of pur- chasing back numbers at a reduced rate. The Library (reference and circulating) and the Reading Rooms are open daily for the convenience of Members. Fi'.LLOwsHiF is attained by election. Caxuioates must be propc-sed and seconded by Fellows of the Society, who, either from personal or general knowledge, vouch for the Candidate's (lualification and eligibility. Un the nomination of the Council, Candidates may be elected as Fellows by a Ballot taken at any Ordinary Meeting of the Society, The srBSCRiPTiON is two ouixkas per annum, and there is at present no entrance fee. REGULATIONS OF THE LIBRARY. 1. The Library and the Reading Room are open daily from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m., except on Saturdays, when they are closed at 1.30 p.m. 2. Every Fellow whose subscription is not in arrear is entitled to consult books and to use the Reading Room. Persons who are non- Fellows may be allowed to use the Library and Reading Room for a definite period on presentation to the Librarian of an introduction by a Member of Council. All cases in which temporary permission has been granted to non-Fellows shall be reported to the Library Com- mittee at its next meeting. No books may be borrowed except by Fellows. 3. Fellows may borrow books from the Library on personal application, or by letter addressed to the Assistant Secretary or Librarian, all expenses for carriage being paid by the borrower. 4. No Fellow may have more than ten volumes out at any one time or keep any book longer than one month, except by special authority from the Chairman of the Library Committee or an Honorary Secretary. 5. Cyclopaedias, books of reference, and unbound scientific journals and periodicals, may be borrowed only on the written order of an Honorary Secretary for a period not exceeding /our days. If books so lent be not returned within the specified time, the borrower shall incur a fine of one shilling ])er day per volume for each day they are detained beyond the time specified. 6. Any Fellow who damages or loses a book shall either replace the work or pay a fine equivalent to its value. 7. Readers are not themselves to replace books taken from the shelves, but to lay them on the Library table. 8. Any infringement of these regulations will involve the suspen- sion of the right to the use of the Library, and shall be reported to the Library Committee at its next meeting. PREFACE. — -^ — A Catalogue of tlie Library of the Eoyal Statistical Society, arranged under authors' names, was published in 1884, and this was supplemented by a subject index in 1886. A second catalosiue was })ublished in 1908, but, owing to the continuous growth of the Library, which now includes nearly 60,000 volumes, it has l)ecome necessary to issue a new one. The present catalogue has been prepared on a plan differing from that previously adoj)ted. It is divided into three parts : I, Authors : II. Official Publications ; III. Miscellaneous, and comjirises (with certain excejjtions named below) all works included in the Library on ^larch 31st. 1921. Contributions to tlie transactions of the Royal Statistical and other Societies, which were included under the authors' names, in previous catalogues, have been omitted altogether, as a complete index to tlie issues of the Journal of the Royal Statistical Society is now being prepared. In consulting the volume the following general rules adopted in its compilation should be noted : — 1 . Official publications (Part II) have been arranged under the name of the country, province, department or city, with subdieadings of the official de]»artments responsible for the publications. Parliatnentary Papers of the United Kingdom are not entered, but an index of these may be seen in the Library 2. Associations, institutions, societies, universities, etc., have been entered under their titles in Part III. Names of British bodies are arranged under the chief word of designation, but titles of foreign associations and societies, etc., remain unaltered. The entries are mainly in chronological order, but in certain cases {f.g., American Economic Association ) where the contributions are numerous it has been found con- venient to give the authors" names in alphabetical order under the main heading. 3. Anonymous books are given under their titles in Part I. 1. Tracts and pamphlets are not entered under the authors' names excejit where several publications by the same author have been bound together. An index of all tracts and pamphlets is available for reference in the Library. ERRATUM. p. 50. For Glutsky, read Slutsky. CATALOGUE. PART I.— AUTHORS. Abbott (Edith). Women in industry.
